metadata.titleEn: Near-surface air temperature data of Antarctic ice sheet (2001-2018)
metadata.description:
1) Data content:  spatial and temporal dataset of near-surface monthly air temperature of Antarctic ice sheet from 2001 to 2018。
2) Data source and processing method: MODIS (MODerate resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) Land Surface Temperature measurements in combination with in-situ air temperature records from 119 meteorological stations are used to reconstruct a monthly near-surface air temperature product over the Antarctic Ice Sheet (AIS) by means of a neural network model. The product is generated on a regular grid of 0.05°×0.05°, spanning from 2001 to 2018.
3) Data quality description: the accuracy is better than that of ERA5 reanalysis data.
4) Data application achievements and prospects: the database can be used to study the temporal and spatial distribution characteristics of near-surface air temperature of Antarctic ice sheet, and the impact of SAM and ENSO on the interannual variation of Antarctic temperature. In addition, the dataset has the potential application for climate model validation and data assimilation due to the independence of the input of a numerical weather prediction model.
metadata.instructions: The data is stored in raster NC format, and the file name is Antarctic_ T2m_ reconstruction_ 2001-2018. nc

background: As a central component of the cryosphere, the Antarctic Ice Sheet (AIS) plays a very important role in the global climate system. Near-surface air temperature is one of the most fundamental factors in the Antarctic system, and its variations affect not only the mass variations of the ice sheet itself, but also the ecological environment, biochemical processes, and species diversity of the surrounding sea areas (Herbei et al. 2016; Convey et al. 2018). From the 1957/58 International Geophysical Year (IGY), a lot of efforts have been put into direct meteorological observations across the Antarctic continent. However, most of the stations are located at the edge of the ice sheet, with only two stations in the interior. Thus, sparseness of observed data is a primary challenge when investigating spatial and variability of temperature over the AIS. Although significant progress has been made to improve climate models including atmospheric general circulation models (AGCMs) and limited area models (LAMs) for polar regions, AGCMs do not adequately represent the effect of topography on air temperature due to their coarse resolution, and the LAMs suffer from the lack of high-quality forcing data at their boundaries, leading to relatively high uncertainties of the simulations. Thanks to the rapid development of satellite remote sensing technology, thermal infrared remote sensing images, which can provide spatially continuous data at a high resolution, have become an important tool to determine global surface skin temperatures.
research objective: Our objective is to reconstruct a monthly near-surface air temperature dataset over the entire grounded AIS from 2001 to 2018, using MODIS LST products in combination with air temperature records from 119 meteorological stations. The resulting air temperature variability is also examined. In addition, the dataset serves to investigate the influence of the Southern Hemisphere annual mode (SAM) on the AIS temperature changes.
challenges: However, most of the stations are located at the edge of the ice sheet, with only two stations in the interior. As a result, it is challenging to represent climate information of the vast Antarctic interior well by relying only on the existing stations. However, the extremely harsh environment (e.g., extreme temperatures and winds) in Antarctica usually results in intermittent gaps of AWS measurements, and hence long-term records are also scarce. Moreover, most of the AIS is still undocumented by AWS observations. AGCMs do not adequately represent the effect of topography on air temperature due to their coarse resolution, and the LAMs suffer from the lack of high-quality forcing data at their boundaries, leading to relatively high uncertainties of the simulations.
methods: The MODIS LST data used in this paper are the monthly average LST datasets MODIS Level 3 data products MOD11C3v006 and MYD11C3v006. A three-layer neural network fitting model is constructed to reconstruct the near-surface temperature field of the Antarctica by using the temperature data from 119 meteorological stations and the corresponding grid data from the MODIS dataset. First, nearest neighbor interpolation is used to extract the preprocessed MODIS LST at the corresponding station locations. The MODIS LST values are matched with the corresponding station records. The input layer integrates and passes information to the hidden layer; each neuron in the hidden layer summarizes the information of the previous layer and transfers it to the output layer through nonlinear activation function. After finishing the neural network training process, the remaining 60% observations are used to verify the reliability of the established quantitative statistical relationship between monthly station air temperature and MODIS LST.
dataset: This compilation contains near-surface air temperature observations from 119 Antarctic weather stations (95 AWSs and 24 manned stations). The MODIS LST data used in this paper are the monthly average LST datasets MODIS Level 3 data products MOD11C3v006 and MYD11C3v006. Here, we utilize MOD11C3v006 data from January 2001 to December 2018, and MYD11C3v006 between July 2002 and December 2018.
findings: Comparison with independent in situ air temperature measurements shows low uncertainty, with a mean bias of 0.098C, a mean absolute error of 2.238C, and a correlation coefficient of 97%. Furthermore, the performance of the reconstruction is better than ERA5 (the fifth-generation ECMWF reanalysis model) against in situ measurements. For the 2001–18 period, the MODIS-based near-surface air temperature product yields annual warming in the East Antarctica, but cooling in the Antarctic Peninsula and West Antarctica. However, they are not statistically significant.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with collecting temperature data in the interior of the Antarctic Ice Sheet?
Definition.Answer: Challenges include the sparse distribution of meteorological stations, as most are located at the edge of the ice sheet with only two in the interior. The harsh environment, extreme temperatures, and winds lead to intermittent gaps in AWS measurements, resulting in scarce long-term records. Additionally, many areas remain undocumented by AWS observations, complicating data collection over the vast interior.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data coverage and accuracy when comparing the use of MODIS LST products with the ERA5 reanalysis model for Antarctic near-surface air temperature observations?
Comparison.Answer: MODIS LST products offer spatially continuous data at a high resolution, allowing for a more detailed reconstruction of near-surface air temperature over the Antarctic Ice Sheet. The MODIS-based method yields lower uncertainty and better performance in comparison to ERA5, with a mean bias of 0.098°C, a mean absolute error of 2.238°C, and a correlation coefficient of 97% against in situ measurements. ERA5, while comprehensive, does not provide the same level of detail due to its reliance on lower-resolution model outputs.

Comparison.Question: In terms of data collection challenges, how does the sparseness of meteorological stations in the Antarctic interior impact the effectiveness of MODIS LST-based reconstructions compared to traditional measurement techniques?
Comparison.Answer: The sparseness of meteorological stations in the Antarctic interior poses significant challenges for both MODIS LST-based reconstructions and traditional measurement techniques. However, the MODIS LST approach mitigates this issue by using satellite data to fill gaps between sparse ground stations, resulting in a more comprehensive and continuous temperature dataset. Traditional techniques rely heavily on the limited number of stations, making it difficult to capture spatial variability across the vast and harsh Antarctic interior.

Interpretation.Question: How can neural network models be leveraged to enhance the accuracy of near-surface temperature reconstructions in polar regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Neural network models can be utilized by integrating satellite-derived data like MODIS LST with meteorological station records to reconstruct near-surface temperature fields. The model's ability to learn complex patterns from data allows it to improve the representation of temperature variability across the Antarctic Ice Sheet, particularly in areas with sparse station coverage.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can MODIS LST data contribute to understanding the spatial and temporal variability of near-surface air temperatures over the Antarctic Ice Sheet?
Interpretation.Answer: MODIS LST data provide high-resolution, spatially continuous thermal infrared imagery that can be used to reconstruct near-surface air temperature datasets. This contributes to understanding the variability by offering detailed insights into temperature changes across different regions and periods, enhancing the accuracy of climate models and supporting investigations into influences like the Southern Hemisphere annual mode.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenge of accurately representing climate information in the vast interior of Antarctica?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge of accurately representing climate information in the vast interior of Antarctica is primarily due to the sparseness of observed data. Most meteorological stations are located at the edge of the ice sheet, and only two stations are in the interior. Additionally, the harsh environment in Antarctica often results in intermittent gaps in AWS measurements, leading to long-term record scarcity. As a result, much of the Antarctic Ice Sheet remains undocumented by AWS observations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it difficult to obtain high-quality data for climate models in polar regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Obtaining high-quality data for climate models in polar regions is difficult because atmospheric general circulation models (AGCMs) have coarse resolutions that do not adequately represent the effect of topography on air temperature. Limited area models (LAMs) also suffer from this issue due to the lack of high-quality forcing data at their boundaries, leading to relatively high uncertainties in simulations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for integrating satellite remote sensing technology with ground station data for reconstructing near-surface temperatures in Antarctica?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for integrating satellite remote sensing technology with ground station data for reconstructing near-surface temperatures in Antarctica arises from the sparseness and limited spatial coverage of ground-based meteorological observations. Satellite remote sensing, such as MODIS LST products, offers spatially continuous data at high resolution, which can be combined with ground station records to create a more comprehensive dataset through methods like neural network models.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of relying on MODIS LST data combined with a limited number of meteorological stations for reconstructing near-surface air temperature over the Antarctic Ice Sheet?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Relying on MODIS LST data combined with a limited number of meteorological stations can lead to challenges in accurately representing climate information of the vast Antarctic interior. Most stations are located at the edge of the ice sheet, and the sparse distribution can result in high uncertainty in the data reconstruction, especially in regions without direct observations. However, this approach can still provide valuable spatially continuous data that is otherwise unavailable due to the harsh environmental conditions limiting direct observations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the implications of using a neural network model to reconstruct near-surface temperature fields in regions with sparse observational data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a neural network model to reconstruct near-surface temperature fields in regions with sparse observational data can enhance the dataset's spatial coverage and accuracy. The model allows for the integration of satellite data and meteorological records, potentially providing a more comprehensive understanding of temperature variability. However, the implications include reliance on the quality of the input data and the model's ability to generalize well in areas with limited direct observations, which could influence the accuracy of the reconstructions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind reconstructing a monthly near-surface air temperature dataset over the Antarctic Ice Sheet using MODIS LST products?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to reconstruct a monthly near-surface air temperature dataset over the entire grounded Antarctic Ice Sheet from 2001 to 2018, using MODIS LST products in combination with air temperature records from 119 meteorological stations. This dataset aims to examine air temperature variability and to investigate the influence of the Southern Hemisphere annual mode (SAM) on the AIS temperature changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is the integration of MODIS LST data and meteorological station records crucial for understanding temperature variations over the Antarctic Ice Sheet?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration is crucial because the sparseness of observed data due to most stations being located at the edge of the ice sheet makes it challenging to represent climate information of the vast Antarctic interior. Additionally, using MODIS LST data provides spatially continuous data at a high resolution, which helps to overcome the limitations of sparse and intermittent meteorological station data.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a neural network model for reconstructing near-surface temperature fields in Antarctica?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing a neural network model is important because it helps to establish a reliable quantitative statistical relationship between monthly station air temperature and MODIS LST. This model effectively reconstructs the near-surface temperature field of Antarctica, addressing challenges such as sparse data coverage and the extreme environmental conditions that lead to data gaps in automatic weather station measurements.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in using MODIS LST products to reconstruct near-surface air temperature datasets for the Antarctic Ice Sheet?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves using monthly average LST datasets from MODIS Level 3 data products (MOD11C3v006 and MYD11C3v006), constructing a three-layer neural network model, extracting preprocessed MODIS LST at meteorological station locations through nearest neighbor interpolation, matching MODIS LST values with corresponding station records, and verifying the neural network model with remaining observations to ensure reliability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the spatial coverage of temperature observations over the Antarctic Ice Sheet be improved given the sparse distribution of meteorological stations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The spatial coverage can be improved by integrating thermal infrared remote sensing data, like MODIS LST, which provides spatially continuous data at high resolution, with existing in-situ temperature records from meteorological stations. This approach helps to model and reconstruct temperature fields across the vast Antarctic interior where station coverage is limited.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the reconstruction of near-surface air temperature datasets over the Antarctic Ice Sheet?
Enablement.Answer: The use of MODIS LST products and neural network models has enabled the reconstruction of monthly near-surface air temperature datasets over the Antarctic Ice Sheet by combining satellite data with records from meteorological stations.

Enablement.Question: How do neural network models enable the accurate estimation of temperature variations in sparsely monitored regions like the Antarctic interior?
Enablement.Answer: Neural network models facilitate accurate estimation by using data from meteorological stations and MODIS LST values to reconstruct the near-surface temperature field. This approach helps to overcome the challenge of sparse station coverage and intermittent data gaps in the Antarctic interior.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the integration of MODIS LST data with meteorological station records enhance the spatial resolution and accuracy of temperature datasets in polar regions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of MODIS LST data with meteorological station records enhances spatial resolution and accuracy by providing spatially continuous data at a high resolution, which helps to address the limitations of coarse-resolution climate models and sparse observational data in polar regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might the neural network model be expected to improve the accuracy of near-surface air temperature reconstructions over the Antarctic Ice Sheet compared to traditional models?
Expectation.Answer: The neural network model utilizes a combination of MODIS LST data and records from 119 meteorological stations to reconstruct temperature fields, allowing for a more detailed analysis by integrating spatially continuous high-resolution satellite data with station observations. This approach can capture complex patterns in the data that traditional models with coarser resolutions may miss.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could be anticipated when using satellite remote sensing data to reconstruct near-surface air temperatures in regions with sparse meteorological stations?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges include accurately representing the vast and varied topography of the Antarctic interior, which is often not well-documented due to the limited number of stations. The harsh environmental conditions can lead to gaps in automatic weather station (AWS) data, making it difficult to create a continuous and reliable dataset without additional interpolation or modeling techniques.

Judgmental.Question: In your judgment, what are the main challenges associated with using neural network models to reconstruct temperature fields in remote regions like Antarctica?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges associated with using neural network models to reconstruct temperature fields in Antarctica include the limited number of meteorological stations, particularly in the interior of the continent, which can restrict the model's ability to accurately capture climate information across the vast region. Additionally, the harsh environmental conditions lead to gaps in Automatic Weather Station (AWS) measurements, making it difficult to obtain long-term records. The neural network model must effectively integrate these sparse and sometimes intermittent data sources to produce reliable temperature fields.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the potential of satellite remote sensing technology in enhancing data collection for climate studies in polar regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Satellite remote sensing technology holds significant potential in enhancing data collection for climate studies in polar regions due to its ability to provide spatially continuous and high-resolution data. This is particularly advantageous in areas like Antarctica, where ground-based observations are limited. The use of thermal infrared remote sensing images from instruments like MODIS helps overcome the challenges posed by the sparse distribution of meteorological stations and the difficulties in maintaining long-term records in harsh environments.

The neural network is trained to establish a quantitative relationship between monthly station air temperature and MODIS LST, and the reliability of this model is verified using the remaining 60% of observations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in representing climate information of the Antarctic interior using available data collection methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the sparse location of weather stations, with most positioned at the edge of the ice sheet and only two in the interior. The harsh Antarctic environment leads to intermittent data gaps in Automatic Weather Station (AWS) measurements, resulting in scarce long-term records. Additionally, most of the Antarctic Ice Sheet remains undocumented by AWS observations, and general circulation models struggle with topographic effects due to coarse resolution.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the data collection techniques that could be used to improve the spatial representation of near-surface air temperature over the Antarctic Ice Sheet.
Request/Directive.Answer: To improve spatial representation, the integration of MODIS Land Surface Temperature (LST) data with in-situ observations from meteorological stations can be employed. A neural network model can be used to reconstruct the temperature field, utilizing MODIS datasets to provide spatially continuous data at high resolution. Techniques like nearest neighbor interpolation can also enhance data extraction at station locations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest potential methodologies for validating the robustness of a dataset constructed from satellite data and meteorological records.
Request/Directive.Answer: A potential methodology for validation could involve comparing the reconstructed dataset with independent in-situ air temperature measurements to assess uncertainty and bias. This could include calculating metrics like mean bias, mean absolute error, and correlation coefficient. Furthermore, comparing the dataset's performance against established reanalysis models, such as ERA5, can help validate its robustness and accuracy.
